results.title: Nokia closer to investment grade without handsets
results.content:
Offloading its handset business for just over $7bn, has done Nokia some favours in credit rating land.

Ratings agency Moody's lifted its rating on the Finnish company two notches to Ba2 from B1 on Monday, putting the company closer to investment grade with a stable outlook.

Analysts pointed to Nokia's push to reduce its debt and a stabilisation in its core networks division.

Nokia announced that it will remain focused on its existing businesses and reduce gross debt, thus positively resolving the uncertainties reflected in the previous developing outlook on the rating

Adding:

The performance of the company's core Networks business will stabilise in the next 12-18 months, despite still intense competition across the communication equipment industry.

In April, Nokia completed the sale of the bulk of its devices and services business to Microsoft.

The company is now focused around three businesses: its networks division, which sells mobile broadband network equipment, its Here mapping business, and a third unit called Technologies, which houses its patent portfolio.

Here is a cheat sheet on Nokia's revamped strategy from the FT's Nordic Correspondent Richard Milne.
results.abstract: Offloading its handset business for just over $7bn, has done Nokia some favours in credit rating land.

results.title: Nokia stands out as European equities rise
results.content:
Europe's main equities markets are making broad gains this morning, with shares in Nokia in demand as investors embrace its strategic overhaul and plans to resume its dividend.

Nokia's stock is up 6.8 at €5.49 and the best single riser on the FTSE Eurofirst 300 after it outlined plans to return €3bn to shareholders via a special dividend and a share buyback. It also named Rajeev Suri, the head of its networks division as its new CEO. as it refocuses operations around its telecoms cabling network business.

Shares in BP are up 1 per cent at 493.5p after its quarterly profit fall came in line with expectations and it raised its dividend.

Norway's oil major is outpacing its UK rival. Statoil is up 4.3 per cent at NKr181 after its first quarter earnings were better than expected.

Swiss engineer ABB is down 6.3 per cent at SFr21.6 after its first quarter net profit fell 18 per cent to $544m, missing consensus forecasts for $726m.

Here are the opening moves across the continent:

  • The FTSE Eurofirst 300 is up 0.6 per cent at 1,344.02

  • Frankfurt's Xetra Dax 30 is up 0.9 per cent at 9,532.90

  • The CAC 40 in Paris is up 0.3 per cent at 4,473.08

  • In London, the FTSE 100 is up 0.6 per cent at 6,737.51
results.abstract: Europe's main equities markets are making broad gains this morning, with shares in Nokia in demand as investors embrace its strategic overhaul and plans to resume its dividend.

results.title: Nokia's sales down 15 per cent as Suri takes helm
results.content:
Nokia earlier on Tuesday outlined its new strategy without its mobile phone business, naming Rajeev Suri, head of its telecoms equipment business, as its new chief executive as it seeks to convince investors that the Finnish group has a bright future after the sale of its once world-leading mobile handset division to Microsoft.

Some of Mr Suri's more immediate challenges, however, can be found in its first quarter results, reports the FT's Richard Milne.

Nokia said on Tuesday that net sales fell by 15 per cent compared with a year earlier, to €2.66bn, while underlying operating profits rose 20 per cent to €304m.

Both were mostly influenced by the networks business, where revenues have been falling and margins increasing as Nokia has focused on the most profitable contracts. But analysts expect the Finnish group to shift its attention to boosting revenue in the future.

Nokia said it expected its network business to increase its revenues in the second half of the year and that its underlying operating margin should be at the upper end of its target range of 5-10 per cent of sales. It had a margin of 9.3 per cent in the first quarter.

Nokia also laid bare the problems at its mobile phone unit sold to Microsoft. Net sales fell by 30 per cent compared with a year earlier to €1.93bn while the underlying operating margin worsened from negative 2.6 per cent to negative 15.9 per cent.
results.abstract: Nokia earlier on Tuesday outlined its new strategy without its mobile phone business, naming Rajeev Suri, head of its telecoms equipment business, as its new chief executive as it seeks to convince investors that the Finnish group has a bright future after the sale of its once world-leading mobile handset division to Microsoft.

results.title: Nokia's new CEO and strategy - the cheat sheet
results.content:
Nokia is dead, long live Nokia! The Finnish company has unveiled its new chief executive, strategy and structure in a blizzard of news. Here is the cheat sheet, from the FT's Nordic Correspondent Richard Milne.

Dividend. Nokia plans to return €3bn to shareholders through a resumption of its dividend (cut last year for the first time in its 148-year history), a special pay-out and a share buyback programme. The sum is made up of ordinary dividends of €400m for 2013 and 2014 as well as a special dividend of about €1bn and a buyback programme of €1.25bn. In addition, Nokia said it wanted to reduce its debt by €2bn in the next two years.

Chief executive. Rajeev Suri, the current head of the new Nokia's biggest division NSN, will be the new chief executive. NSN represents about 90 per cent of the new Nokia's revenues. "As Nokia opens this new chapter, the Nokia Board and I are confident that Rajeev is the right person to lead the company forward," Risto Siilasmaa, Nokia's chairman, said in a statement.

Strategy. Nokia named three key areas of what it calls the new world of technology where it wants to be a leader. They are: telecoms equipment capable of handling a huge increase in the number of devices and data usage; location services; innovation, including in sensing, radio and low power technologies.

Structure. Not surprisingly, this new strategy coincides with the three divisions it has: Networks (the old NSN business), its Here mapping business, and what it calls its Technologies unit, which consists of its patents portfolio. What is not in its new plan is any idea of whether Nokia will use its cash not just for dividends and buybacks but for M&A, particularly to boost its Networks business.
results.abstract: Nokia is dead, long live Nokia! The Finnish company has unveiled its new chief executive, strategy and structure in a blizzard of news. Here is the cheat sheet, from the FT's Nordic Correspondent Richard Milne.

results.title: How Nokia became a networks business: a chart
results.content:
As Nokia has appointed its new CEO, networks chief Rajeev Suri, here is a look at how the Finnish group's networks business came to eclipse the mobile division it just sold off.

The below chart, compiled with data from Capital IQ and Nokia, illustrates how gross profit in Nokia's handset business, which is now going to Microsoft along with former CEO Stephen Elop, declined over the years to the point it was taken over by the mobile networks infrastructure business.

Nokia acquired the remaining stake in the infrastructure business that it did not already own from Siemens this year.

Suri has been running the networks business since 2009, during which time its gross profits increased steadily as the handset division slowed.

Note: Nokia did not disclose gross profit for handsets in 2013, as it agreed to sell the business to Microsoft last September. Its discontinued operations, however, reported gross profit of €2.2bn last year.
results.abstract: As Nokia has appointed its new CEO, networks chief Rajeev Suri, here is a look at how the Finnish group's networks business came to eclipse the mobile division it just sold off.

results.title: Nokia names Rajeev Suri new CEO
results.content:
Just days after completing the sale of its handsets division to Microsoft, Nokia has named its networks head Rajeev Suri as its new chief executive as it focuses the company around the networks business that will now contribute the lion's share of its profits, as well as its technology and mapping units.

Indian-born Suri replaces former Nokia chief Stephen Elop, who has moved over to Microsoft as executive vice president of the mobile devices business, taking 25,000 Nokia staff with him as well as the Finnish group's gadgets including Lumia smartphones and tablets.

Nokia was criticised for missing the crucial pivot in the mobile phone market at around 2007, when profits began to shift from the hardware vendors to software developers.

Elop joined Nokia in September 2010, and despite his strong software background was unable to make the company profitable during his tenure. His strategy of tying Nokia handsets to Windows operating systems failed to stop sales being eclipsed by Samsung and Apple devices.

From 2011 to 2013, the company lost almost €5bn, although last year's net loss was the smallest in three years at €615m.
results.abstract: Just days after completing the sale of its handsets division to Microsoft, Nokia has named its networks head Rajeev Suri as its new chief executive as it focuses the company around the networks business that will now contribute the lion's share of its profits, as well as its technology and mapping units.

results.title: Nokia completes phone sale to Microsoft
results.content:
Nokia has finally hung up on handsets, with the Finnish company announcing its delayed deal to sell the bulk of its Devices & Services business to Microsoft has just been completed.

The SP from Espoo is that the deal has been done at a slightly higher price than the original figure of €5.44bn, although Nokia did not provide the new figure in its statement.

The deal was announced last September, but completion had been delayed beyond the first quarter as it awaited approval from Chinese regulators - finally issued on April 8.

Other adjustments to the deal beside the price, detailed in the Nokia statement:

  • Nokia and Microsoft made certain adjustments to the scope of the assets originally planned to transfer. These adjustments included Nokia's manufacturing facilities in Chennai in India and Masan in the Republic of Korea not transferring to Microsoft. These adjustments have no impact on the material deal terms of the transaction and Nokia will be materially compensated for any retained liabilities.

The Indian manufacturing facility is subject to an asset freeze by the Indian tax authorities, due to ongoing tax proceedings, and means Nokia will still produce phones from here for Microsoft under a service agreement, and they would be expected to carry the new Microsoft Mobile brand.

The company is to close the Korean facility, where 200 people are employed.

Microsoft has also issued its own statement on the closing of the deal , along with this fetching photo of chief executive Satya Nadella and former Nokia chief Stephen Elop sharing a moment together:

results.title: Nokia warns 30,000 chargers potentially unsafe
results.content:
Nokia has warned users of its Lumia 2520 tablet to stop plugging in its charger - or risk an electric shock.

In a product advisory affecting around 30,000 AC-300 chargers that come with the tablet, Nokia said:

Under certain conditions, the plastic cover of the charger's exchangeable plug could come loose and separate. If loose and separated, certain internal components may cause an electric shock if touched while the plug remains in the live socket.

Consumers in Austria, Denmark, Finland, Germany, Russia, Switzerland, the UK and US are "strongly advised to suspend use of the charger until further notice".

Jo Harlow, Smart Devices executive vice president, said:

While there have been no confirmed consumer incidents related to this potential quality issue, product quality and safety are top priorities at Nokia.

The charger is made by a third-party supplier and sales of it as an accessory have now been halted temporarily.
results.abstract: Nokia has warned users of its Lumia 2520 tablet to stop plugging in its charger - or risk an electric shock.

results.title: Nokia-Microsoft deal close on China approval
results.content:
The main regulatory hurdle that prevented Microsoft completing the takeover of Nokia's handset and services businesses in the first quarter has been overcome, with China approving the deal.

Nokia shares are up 2.7 per cent at €5.47 in Helsinki on the news.

Nokia said last month it expected the transaction to close in April, compared to expectations of it doing so in the first quarter, when the €5.4bn deal was first announced last September.

While regulatory approval from the European Commission and the US Department of Justice had been received, it cited "pending approvals from certain antitrust authorities in Asia which are still conducting their reviews".

It announced today it had received regulatory approval from the Ministry of Commerce in China, meaning April is still the target.

The deal included Microsoft paying €1.65bn to license Nokia patents and the company added:

The regulatory approval process has involved a thorough review of Nokia's patent licensing practices by several competition authorities around the world. During that process, no authority has challenged Nokia's compliance with its FRAND undertakings related to standard-essential patents (licensing on fair, reasonable and non-discriminatory terms) or requested that Nokia make changes to its licensing program or royalty terms.
results.abstract: The main regulatory hurdle that prevented Microsoft completing the takeover of Nokia's handset and services businesses in the first quarter has been overcome, with China approving the deal.

results.title: Fast Europe: Tech stocks head fallers
results.content:
With the tech-heavy Nasdaq dropping 2.6 per cent to lead US stock market falls on Friday, investors are selling technology company stocks as the bourses open in Europe on Monday.

Arm Holdings is the biggest faller on the FTSE 100 in London, with the chip designer down 2.5 per cent at 971.5p.

On the FTSE 250 mid-cap index, fellow chip designer Imagination Technologies is the biggest faller - down 2.3 per cent at 209.6p.

In Helsinki, Nokia is down 2.5 per cent at €5.39.

The main bourses are all lower:

  • The FTSE 100 is off two-thirds of a per cent or 45 points at 6,651

  • The Xetra Dax in Frankfurt is down 1.4 per cent or 131 points at 9,565.

  • The Cac 40 in Paris is down 0.5 per cent or 23 points at 4,461.

  • The FTSE Eurofirst 300 is down 1 per cent or 12 points at 1,340.

Cement makers are bucking the trend after news of the mega-merger between Holcim and Lafarge. Lafarge is up 4.2 per cent to its highest since September 2008, and Holcim has soared 7.4 per cent to a four year high,

There is little in the way of data points to influence markets today. German industrial output for February has come in a tad better than expected - growing 0.4 per cent compared to expectations of 0.3 per cent, and Spanish industrial output exceeded forecasts in February.

The eurozone Sentix index for April is due at 9.30am London time, with investor confidence expected to rise to 14.2 from 13.9 last month.
results.abstract: With the tech-heavy Nasdaq dropping 2.6 per cent to lead US stock market falls on Friday, investors are selling technology company stocks as the bourses open in Europe on Monday.
